p: Culture is the most common method in microbiology to isolate and identify microorganisms. However, that is a very difficult task to apply on ancient sources because of bacterial survival and suitable media of growth (Vishnivetskaya et al., 2006). Among bacteria found in ancient dental pulp, Mycobacterium tuberculosis can enter a dormant state during its life cycle and resists well to the environment and infected host. PCR testing for M. tuberculosis on samples of 300‐year‐old mummies yielded positive results but the culture method results were negative (Lemma et al., 2008).
